642.06
   955.01  SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the Tree Ordinance of the
City of Aurora, Ohio.
(Ord. 1991-128.  Passed 10-23-91.)
   955.02  DEFINITIONS.
   As used within this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings set
forth in this section:
   (a)   "Tree" means:
      (1)   Any living woody plant with needles or scaletype leaves that has a
well defined stem or stems with a diameter of at least six inches at four and
one-half feet from the surface of the ground.
      (2)   Any living, self-supporting woody broad leaf plant that has a well-
defined stem or stems with a diameter of at least two inches at four and one-
half feet from the surface of the ground.
      (3)   Any living self-supporting woody plant that has a well-defined stem
or stems which has been intentionally cultivated and established.
   (b)   "Public trees" includes all trees now or hereafter growing on any
street, park or any other public site.
   (c)   "Streets, alleys, highways or ways" mean the entire width of every
public way or right of way when any part thereof is open to the use of the
public, as a matter of right, for purposes of vehicular and pedestrian traffic.
   (d)   "Property line" means the legal boundary line between private and
City-owned land.
   (e)   "Tree lawn" means that part of a street not covered by a sidewalk or
other paving, lying between the property line and that portion of the street
usually used for vehicular traffic.
   (f)   "Property owner" means the person owning such property as shown by the
County Auditor's Plat of Portage County, State of Ohio.
   (g)   "Large trees" are designated as those attaining a height of forty-five
feet or more.
   (h)   "Medium trees" are designated as those attaining a height of thirty to
forty-five feet.
   (i)   "Small trees" are designated as those under thirty feet.
   (j)   "Remove or removal" means the removal of all above and below ground
parts, including the stump and roots.
   (k)   "Diameter at breast height, (D.B.H.)" means a tree's diameter in
inches measured by a diameter tape at four and one-half feet from the surface
of the ground.  On trees having multiple stems, the largest diameter stem will
be measured.
   (l)   "Parks" includes any City public spaces designated for recreation and/
or conservation.
   (m)   "Public site" includes any other ground owned by the City.
   (n)   "Dripline" means the approximately circular vertical extension to the
ground of the outer most branches and/or leaves of the tree as an indication of
the spread of the root system.
      (Ord. 1991-128.  Passed 10-23-91.)
   955.03  CREATION AND ESTABLISHMENT OF A TREE COMMISSION.
   (a)   There is hereby created and established a Tree Commission for the City
of Aurora. This Commission shall be composed of one (1) member of Council and
six (6) citizens, all of whom shall be residents of the City. The member of
Council shall be elected by Council. The Mayor shall appoint all of the citizen
members who shall serve for the overlapping four (4) year terms, with two (2)
citizen members' terms expiring each year at the end of the calendar year. The
City Arborist shall be an ex-officio member. Any member may resign at any time
upon written notice to the Mayor. Except for any such resignation, each member
of the Commission shall serve until his/her successor has been appointed or
elected.
   (b)   Within thirty days following the expiration of the term of any
appointed Tree Commissioner, a successor shall be appointed by the Mayor with
the approval of Council, and the successor shall serve a term of four years.
Successive terms shall be permitted, but in no case shall any member serve more
than a four year term without re-appointment and re-confirmation by Council. A
vacancy occurring during the term of any member of the Tree Commission shall be
filled for the unexpired term in the manner authorized for an original
appointment. A member may be removed by the Mayor with the approval of Council.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.04  DIRECTOR/CITY ARBORIST.
   The City Arborist shall serve as the Administrator of the Tree Commission,
and is required to attend meetings, unless otherwise notified by the
Commission.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.05  COMPENSATION.
   Members appointed to the Tree Commission shall serve without compensation,
but shall be entitled to reimbursement for any and all necessary expenditures
in carrying out the duties of such Commission.  The Tree Commission may retain
the services of qualified professionals in addition to the City Arborist as may
be necessary to facilitate the functions of the Commission. 
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.06  OPERATION.
   (a)   The Tree Commission shall meet once a month and shall hold an
organizational meeting in January of each year. During its annual
organizational meeting, the Commission shall elect a Chairman and Vice-
Chairman. A majority of the voting members shall constitute a quorum and any
actions of the Tree Commission may be taken by the majority vote of the members
present at the meeting at which the action is taken. The Mayor shall appoint a
City employee as secretary to the Tree Commission who shall keep minutes of its
meetings and file them with the Clerk of Council. A Special Meeting may be
called by the Chairman, the Vice-Chairman, or by any two voting members.
   (b)   The Tree Commission shall be placed within the domain of the Parks &
Recreation Department.  The Department Head, Assistant Department Head or
Manager shall  serve in a non-elected, advisory role upon the request of the
Commission and in the absence of the City Arborist. 
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   (c)   Absence of a Member of the Commission, without justifiable excuse as
determined by a majority of the Commission, from three (3) consecutive meetings
of the Commission, shall be grounds for removal of the member from the
Commission.
(Ord.  2002-168.  Passed 8-26-02.)
   955.07  DUTIES.
   The duties of the Tree Commission shall be as follows:
   (a)   To study the problems and determine the needs of the City in
connection with a tree planting and beautification program and/or the City's
Master Tree Plan.
   (b)   To consider, revise and administer the City's Master Tree Plan which
is to be updated every two (2) years.
   (c)   When requested by Council, to consider, investigate, make findings,
report and recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the
scope of the Tree Commission's duties.
   (d)   To recommend to the City Arborist or his/her designees, the location,
type and kind of trees to be planted upon City streets and/or in City Parks.
   (e)   To assist the Director of Parks and Recreation, the City Arborist or
his/her designees, as well as Council and the residents of the City, in the
dissemination of news and information regarding the selection, planting and
maintenance of trees within the corporate limits.
   (f)   To work in conjunction with civic and public interest groups devoted
to tree care and preservation.
   (g)   To discuss at its regular and special meetings the subject of trees,
insofar as they relate to the City, and all other aspects of the City tree
program.
   (h)   Upon request of a City official and/or Commission, to review, comment,
and consult with the Director of Planning and Zoning or his/her designee and/or
the Planning Commission to assist him/her/them in reviewing plans for
residential, commercial, and industrial developments and/or any other
improvement or modification of undeveloped land, in order to ascertain the
number and size of trees proposed to be removed, whether from building sites or
otherwise, and to make recommendations to him/her/them,  can be communicated
through the City Arborist, concerning the retention of existing trees on such
sites and the planting of new trees in areas where trees have been removed. Any
City Arborist recommendations regarding the foregoing shall first be brought
before the Tree Commission for its review and approval.
   (i)   The Tree Commission Chairman, the Secretary to the Tree Commission,
the Parks & Recreation Advisor, and the Arborist should work together on any
Tree Commission recommendation concerning the planting and/or removal of trees
in the City right-of-way and disseminating this information to the appropriate
parties.
      (Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.08  MASTER TREE PLAN.
   The City Arborist shall have the authority to formulate a Master Tree Plan
which shall be reviewed by the Tree Commission. The Master Tree Plan shall
include the inventory of existing public trees and shall specify the
requirements for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting and
removal or disposition of trees in parks, along streets, on other public sites,
and on other undeveloped land, and shall specify the species of trees planted
in any of these areas. Upon the adoption or revision of the Master Tree Plan,
it shall be presented to Council, and upon its acceptance and approval shall
constitute the official comprehensive Master Tree Plan for the City.  From and
after the effective date of the Master Tree Plan, or any amendment thereto, all
planting shall conform thereto.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.09  TREE SPECIES TO BE PLANTED.
   The Tree Commission shall develop and maintain a list of desirable large,
medium and small trees for planting in parks, along streets and on other public
sites based on mature height.  (Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.10  SPACING.
   The spacing of trees planted along streets will be in accordance with the
three species, size classes listed pursuant to Section
955.09. No trees may be planted closer than the following: large trees, fifty
feet; medium trees, forty feet; and small trees, thirty feet; except in special
plantings designated or approved by the Director of Planning and Zoning or his/
her designee and by the City Arborist. No property owner shall plant a tree
within a pubic right of way without first obtaining the written approval of the
Director of Planning and Zoning or his/her designee and/or the City Arborist.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.11  DISTANCE FROM CURB AND SIDEWALK.
   The distance trees may be planted from curbs or curblines and sidewalks will
be in accordance with the three species size classes listed in Section
955.09.  No trees may be planted closer to any curb, curbline or sidewalk than
the following:  large trees, four feet;  medium trees, three feet; and small
trees, two feet.
(Ord. 1991-128.  Passed 10-23-91.)
   955.12  DISTANCE FROM STREET CORNERS AND FIRE HYDRANTS.
   No tree shall be planted closer than thirty-five feet from any street
corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines.  No
tree shall be planted closer than ten feet from any fire hydrant.
(Ord. 1991-128.  Passed 10-23-91.)
   955.13  UTILITIES.
   No public tree other than those species referred to as small trees as listed
pursuant to Section
955.09 may be planted under or within ten lateral feet of any overhead utility
wire, over or within five lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer
pipe or other utility line or pipe.  (Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.14  PUBLIC TREE CARE.
   The City shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove all
public trees, as may be necessary to insure public safety or to preserve or
enhance the symmetry and beauty of public sites. The Director of Planning and
Zoning or his/her designee and/or the City Arborist may remove or cause to be
removed, any public tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or
which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas
lines, water lines or other public improvements, or is affected with any
injurious disease, insect or fungus. 
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.15  REMOVAL, REPLANTING AND REPLACEMENT OF PUBLIC TREES.
   (a)   Whenever it is necessary to remove a public tree in connection with
the paving of a sidewalk or the widening of the portion of a street or highway,
the City shall cause the tree to be replanted or replaced with tree species
listed pursuant to Section
955.09. This requirement will be satisfied if an equivalent number of trees are
planted at the nearest appropriate location as determined by the City Arborist.
   (b)   No person shall remove a public tree for the purpose of construction
or any other reason without the written permission of the City Arborist. The
City Arborist may require replacement of a removed tree as a condition of such
approval. Such replacement shall be in accordance with the species listed
pursuant to Section
955.09. The person or property owner shall bear the cost of removal and
replacement of all such public trees.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.16  TOPPING OF PUBLIC TREES.
   It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm or City
Director or a City employee under the Director's supervision to top any public
tree. Topping is defined as the serve cutting back of limbs to stubs larger
than three inches in diameter so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure
the tree. Public trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain
trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices
are impractical may be exempted from this chapter at the determination of the
City Arborist.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.17  OBSTRUCTION; TREES PRUNED.
   It shall be the duty of any person or persons owing or occupying real
property bordering on any street upon which property there may be trees, to
prune such trees in such manner that they will not obstruct or shade the street
lights, obstruct the passage of pedestrians on sidewalks, obstruct the vision
of traffic signs or obstruct the view of any street intersection. Such persons
shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs,
which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The minimum clearance of
any overhanging portion thereof shall be eight feet over sidewalks and twelve
feet over all streets except truck thoroughfares, which shall have a clearance
of sixteen feet.
   (a)   Notice to Prune. Should any person or persons owing real property
bordering on any street fail to prune trees as hereinabove provided, the
Director of Planning and Zoning or his/her designee and/or the City Arborist
shall order such person or persons to so prune such trees within ten days after
receipt of written notice.
   (b)   Order Required. The order herein shall be served by certified mail to
the last known address of the property owner.
   (c)   Failure to Comply. When a person, to whom an order is directed, fails
to comply within the specified time, it shall be lawful for the City to prune
such trees and to assess the property owner for the cost of services rendered.
      (Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.18  RESERVED.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
955.18  was deleted by Ordinance 2001-317.  This section is reserved for future
legislation.)
   955.19  ABUSE AND/OR MUTILATION OF PUBLIC TREES.
   Unless specifically authorized by the Director of Planning and Zoning or
his/her designee and/or the City Arborist, no person shall intentionally
damage, cut, carve, transplant, whether above or below ground, or transplant or
remove any public tree; attach any rope, wire, nails, advertising posters or
other contrivance to any public tree; allow any gaseous liquid or solid
substance which is harmful to such trees to come in contact with them; or set
fire or permit any fire to burn when such fire or heat therefrom will injure
any portion of any public tree. No person shall pour salt water or a chemical
or chemicals upon any street in such a way as to injure any tree planted or
growing thereon. The City shall not be restricted in the use of anti-icing
materials.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.20  PLACING MATERIALS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain upon any public place of
the City, any stone, brick, sand,  concrete or other materials which may impede
the free passage of water, air and fertilizer to the roots of any public tree
growing therein, except by written approval of the Director of Planning and
Zoning or his/her designee and/or the City Arborist.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.21  PROTECTION OF PUBLIC TREES.
   (a)    All public trees located near any excavation or construction of any
building, structure, or street work, shall be guarded with a good substantial
fence, frame, or box not less than four feet high placed at the dripline. All
laborers, building material, dirt or other debris shall be kept outside this
barrier. The Director of the Planning and Zoning or his/her designee and/or the
City Arborist may permit a variance in cases where the barrier would impede the
flow of traffic on street, private street or driveway and where the dripline
overhangs a building or permanent structure.
   (b)   No person shall excavate any ditches or trenches within the dripline
of a public tree or lay any drive within fifteen feet of a public tree without
first obtaining the approval of the Director of Planning and Zoning or his/her
designee and/or the City Arborist.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.22  PUBLIC UTILITY COMPANIES.
   Public utility companies shall notify the Director of Planning and Zoning
and/or the City Arborist prior to pruning any public tree for the purpose of
maintaining safe line clearance and shall carry out all such work in accordance
with accepted arboricultural standards. If accepted arboricultural standards
are not followed, the Director of Planning and Zoning and/or the City Arborist
will immediately file a formal complaint with the Public Utilities Commission.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.23  EMERGENCIES.
   In the case of officially declared emergencies, such as windstorms, ice
storms, or other disasters, the requirements shall be waived so that the
requirements of  this chapter would in no way hinder public and/or private work
to restore order in the City. This work shall follow maintenance standards as
outlined by the Director of Planning and Zoning and/or by the City Arborist. 
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.24  MOVING LARGE OBJECTS.
   No person shall move any building or other large object that may injure
public trees, or parts thereof, without the written approval of the Director of
Planning and Zoning and/or the City Arborist.  (Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-
02.)
   955.25  INTERFERENCE WITH THE DIRECTOR OF PLANNING AND ZONING OR HIS/HER
DESIGNEE, THE TREE COMMISSION AND/OR THE  CITY ARBORIST.
   No person shall hinder, prevent, delay or interfere with the Director of
Planning and Zoning or his designee, the Tree Commission, and/or the City
Arborist or any of its/their agents, while engaged in carrying out the
execution or enforcement of this chapter; provided, however, that nothing
herein shall be construed as an attempt to prohibit the pursuit of any remedy,
legal or equitable, in any court of competent jurisdiction for the protection
of property rights by the owner of any property within the City.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.26  REGISTRATION OF TREE EXPERTS.
   (a)   To protect the public, the City shall require any person or firm
engaged in the business of public tree maintenance and/or removal to be
licensed by the City.
      (1)   The license fee shall be in compliance with Section
1329.01(e)(1).
         (Ord. 1992-74.  Passed 4-29-92.)
      (2)   Before any license shall be issued, each applicant shall first file
evidence verifying:
         A.   Coverage by Workers' Compensation.
         B.   Liability insurance coverage in the minimum amounts of one
million dollars ($1,000,000) for bodily injury and one million dollars
($1,000,000) for damage to property to cover and save harmless the City and its
agents from all suits, claims or actions of every class and nature for or on
persons or property damage caused or claimed to be caused, directly or
indirectly by the conduct of the work contemplated, or by acts of strangers, or
any conditions due to the elements or any defects or insufficiencies in any
method, material, ways, machinery, equipment or apparatus used in connection
with the work.
         C.   Bonding.
         D.   Certification by the Ohio Chapter of the International Society of
Arboriculture.
   (b)   No license shall be required of any public service company including
utilities and their agents and contractors or employees of the City doing such
work in the pursuit of their public service endeavors.
(Ord. 1991-128.  Passed 10-23-91.)
   955.27  COMMISSION AS TRUSTEE.
   The Tree Commission may act as trustee for any property, assets or funds
donated to the Municipality for the care and maintenance of public trees,
provided the donor designates or provides for the designation of the Commission
as such trustee.  In such an event, the Commission shall have all those powers
and duties necessary to carry out the purpose of the trust.
(Ord. 1991-128.  Passed 10-23-91.)
   955.28  ESTABLISHMENT OF A BUDGET.
   (a)    The various funds of the City, listed under the General Fund, and
known as The Tree Commission Funds, (or line item budget account) is hereby
established which is to be utilized for the receipt of license and permit fees,
bond moneys generally, grant moneys, damages, penalties and donations. These
funds shall be held and/or deposited with the City through its Finance
Director. Any funds budgeted for expense in this area shall be in conjunction
with, and/or as a part of, the City's budget for its Parks and Recreation
Department, with its own isolated subcategories within that budget.  Any
disbursement must be solely for the purpose of encouraging the planting,
maintenance and relocation of public trees within the City under the
jurisdiction of the Tree Commission.
   (b)   The Director of Finance is authorized and directed to receive such
moneys at intermittent intervals, so segregate them into a line item budget
account for the purpose herein mentioned, and thereafter to periodically
disburse any funds that shall be appropriated to provide for the planning,
maintenance and relocation of public trees, within the City under the
jurisdiction of the Tree Commission.
   (c)   The Parks & Recreation Department will be the holding entity for Tree
Commission monies in the Department’s Enterprise accounts.  All expenditures
concerning the Tree Commission in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00)
shall not be expended without the approval of the Tree Commission.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.29  MEMORIAL TREE GROVE.
   The Tree Commission shall establish and maintain the Memorial Tree Grove
Fund or budget and appropriate necessary moneys for the replacement of trees,
maintenance of trees, and for the future planting of trees or gardens
established within the Memorial Tree Grove. The members, with the assistance of
the City Arborist, will be responsible for the establishment of planting
schedules and cost of trees.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.30  LANDMARK TREE REGISTRY PROGRAM
   The Tree Commission may set up a registry program of Landmark Trees (the
largest of a given species) on public and private land.  When such a tree has
been designated on public lands, every effort must be taken to protect it.  If
a landmark tree is identified on private land under development, the Tree
Commission shall recommend to the Planning Commission to work with the
developer to preserve and protect it according to the recommendation of the
City Arborist. 
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.31  CITY ARBORIST.
   The Mayor shall appoint the City Arborist, who shall be certified by the
International Society of Arboriculture. The City Arborist shall be appointed at
the beginning of each Mayor's term. The Mayor's appointment of the City
Arborist shall be effective unless rejected, by not later than the next
regularly scheduled Council meeting after the appointment is announced, by more
than two-thirds (2/3rds) of the members elected to Council. The City Arborist
may be removed from office by the Mayor. The Mayor's removal of the City
Arborist shall be effective unless rejected, by not later than the next
regularly scheduled Council meeting after the removal is announced, by more
than two-thirds (2/3rds) of the members elected to Council. At any time there
is no City Arborist serving the City, the Tree Commission may act in place of
the City Arborist in reviewing, granting or denying the consents and/or the
approvals required of the City Arborist under this Chapter
955.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.32  SEVERABILITY.
   Should any section, clause or provision of this chapter be declared by the
courts to be invalid, the same shall not affect the validity of the chapter as
a whole, or parts thereof, other than the part so declared to be invalid.
(Ord. 1991-128.  Passed 10-23-91.)
   955.33  CONFLICT.
   In the event of a conflict between any provision of this chapter, including
any rules and regulations adopted pursuant to its provisions and any provisions
of any other ordinances of the City including any rules and regulations adopted
pursuant to such ordinances, the more restrictive provision or provisions shall
prevail.
(Ord. 1991-128.  Passed 10-23-91.)
   955.34  PROPOSED DEVELOPMENT PLAN
   (a)   The site plan for any proposed development or improvement of any tract
or parcel of land in the City shall be evaluated by the Tree Commission upon
referral by the Planning Commission. The Director of Planning and Zoning or
his/her designee and/or the City Arborist may inspect any site the
consideration of which has been placed on the agenda of the Planning Commission
and prior to any approval of preliminary and/or final site plan by Council. The
Director of Planning and Zoning or his/her designee and/or the City Arborist
may inspect a development at any time during development, redevelopment,
renovation or razing thereafter.
   (b)   Any site plan submitted to the Planning Commission shall include the
following:
      (1)   An accurate scale drawing, prepared by a certified arborist,
landscape architect or person determined as qualified by the Director of
Planning and Zoning and the City Arborist, drawn at an accurate scale,
detailing curb cuts, utility installations, paving, grade changes, drainage
improvements, existing trees, tree wells and proposed buildings and structures.
The site plan shall include a full landscape plan that includes the following:
plant species, plant sizes at installation, plant qualities, plant locations in
relationship to the property and proposed building, plant ledger, installation
specifications no less than as recommended by the American Nursery Association
Planting Specifications, new tree installation and staking procedures.
      (2)   Approximate location, size, species and condition of all existing
trees. Trees to be charted are (1) any living woody plant with needles or
scale-type leaves that has a well defined stem or stems with a diameter of at
least 6 inches (6") at four and one half feet (4 W) from the surface of the
ground, (2) any living, self supporting woody plant that has a well defined
stem or stems with a diameter of at least four inches (4") at four and one half
feet (4 W) from the surface of the ground and (3) any woody self supporting
plant that has a well-defined stem or stems which has been intentionally
cultivated and established. Trees to be maintained shall be shown in blue.
Trees to be removed shall be shown in red.
      (3)   Specification documents for:
         A.   Protection of existing trees during the development,
redevelopment, renovation or razing;
         B.   Grade changes or other work within a tree's dripline;
         C.   Disposal of trees to be removed. All debris shall be discarded by
the developer. The area shall be made safe prior to the end of each working
day.
         D.   Any new planting and/or tree replacement, specifying the
location, species, size and a completion date for the proposed work.
         E.   The items specified in the Developer's Plans as submitted and
approved by the Planning Commission shall be included in the Developer's
Performance Guarantee as required by Section
1107.07 of the Subdivision Regulations. Such performance guarantee shall cover
the completion of all requirements under this Chapter.
         F.   A site inspection shall be performed by the City Arborist or
representative of the Director of Planning and Zoning. The inspection costs
shall be included in the City Engineer's Estimate of Costs and charged to
Developer's Costs pursuant to  Section
1107.07 of the Subdivision Regulations. Failure of a Developer to adhere and
perform the specific requirements of this Section will not trigger any
enforcement under Section
955.99.  These requirements are subject to the Performance Guarantee and
Insurance Provisions of Section
1101.09 of the Subdivision Regulations.
            (Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
   955.99  PENALTY.
   Any person or firm violating any provision of this chapter or who fails to
comply with any notice issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, upon
being found guilty of violation, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for each separate offense. Each day during which any
violation of the provisions of this chapter shall occur or continue shall be a
separate offense. If, as the result of the violation of any provision of this
chapter, the injury, mutilation or death of a tree is caused, the cost of
repair or replacement of such tree shall be borne by the party in violation.
The replacement value of trees shall be determined in accordance with the
latest revision of "Valuation of Landscape Trees, Shrubs and Other Plants," as
published by the International Society of Arboriculture.
(Ord.  2001-317.  Passed 1-14-02.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 957
Street Signs
957.01    Street sign policy.
CROSS REFERENCES
Signs - see P. & Z. Ch.
1159
   957.01  STREET SIGN POLICY
   The City shall be responsible for the cost of construction, installation,
maintenance and, if required, replacement of the city’s standard street signs
for all publicly dedicated streets.  If a developer or homeowner association
wishes to install alternate signs, rather than the standard signs, they may be
authorized by the city providing the design, construction and location is
approved by the Planning Commission and the Architectural Board of Review.  The
cost of the alternate signs, installation, maintenance and replacement are the
responsibility of the developer and/or homeowner association.  If the alternate
signs fall into disrepair, and the homeowner association petitions the City to
replace the alternate signs, the City is authorized to replace the alternate
signs with the standard sign.  The City will be responsible for the cost of
removal of the alternate sign, the cost of construction, installation and
maintenance of the replacement standard signs.
(Ord. 2003-184.  Passed 10-13-03.)
